description:
A safe workplace considers your physical, psychological, and social well being.

Your safety at work is protected by three pieces of [legislation]:

The Alberta Occupational Health and Safety Act (OHS Act) protects most workers in Alberta.

Federal workers, live-in caregivers, farmworkers, and others may have different laws.  These laws protect workers. 

They are for workers and employers. The Alberta Workers’ Compensation Board (WCB) also covers most injured workers.

content.description:
Services are free.

Alberta Workers’ Health Centre provides a first point of contact for workers with health and safety issues in their workplace. They will provide support, public legal education, and referrals.
Calgary Workers' Resource Centre provides free case work and a public legal education program if you are having issues with your rights in your workplace.

Employment Standards Contact Centre can answer questions related to wages, overtime, vacation pay, hours or form, and termination of employment. 

Hours: 8:15 am to 4:30 pm MT
(Monday to Friday, closed statutory holidays)

The Alberta Occupational Health and Safety (AOHS) Contact Centre can answer questions related to workplace hazards. Contact them if you or anyone else are in danger of injury. 

IMPORTANT: You may also file an anonymous complaint through AOHS.

The Workers’ Compensation Board Alberta can answer questions related to workplace injuries and benefits.

IMPORTANT: You may also report a workplace injury through WCB.

covidSteps.description: You cannot lose your job because of COVID-19.
If you have COVID-19, you should tell your manager.
You should stay home and follow the advice of Alberta Health Services by calling 811.
You must isolate for 14 days or as directed by the AHS.
Depending on your work, you might get paid leave during this time. There may be government benefits you can access.

finalParagraph:
If you catch COVID-19 from your workplace, you should file WCB paperwork and apply for paid leave.  

You should also tell your employer because it affects the safety of other people you work with. Your employer needs to consider your privacy in these cases. 

For more information, refer to:
mainParagraph:
Due to COVID-19, there is a pandemic in Canada. COVID-19 affects worker safety.

Although employers must make work safe for workers during this time, many workers, such as health care aides, are at more risk because of workplace contact. 

Employers should keep employees safe and make sure employees understand how to work safely.
subHeading: What if I test positive for COVID-19?

finalParagraph: Employment Standards apply to most workers. People who work in some fields such as live-in workers, truckers, farmworkers, and firefighters have their own set of rules.
mainParagraph:
Workers and employers in Alberta must follow the Employment Standards Code and Employment Standards Regulation.

The Employment Standards Code creates Alberta’s minimum standards of employment in areas outside of health and safety that are related to the workplace. These include wages, hours of work, overtime, vacation and holidays, leaves, and termination of employment.

It also establishes the steps to follow in cases where employment standards have not been met, such as wrongful [termination] of employment.

Employment standards can be [complicated]. If you are confused about things like being wrongfully fired or are not being paid correctly, call Alberta Employment Standards to find out more. If they don’t know the answer, they will point you in the right direction.

paragraph1:
In addition to laws for health and safety protections, workers' compensation benefits and employment [standards], Alberta has laws that relate to the rights of all people, regardless of their race, religion, source of income, gender, age, or [sexual orientation]. 

Refer to this Human Rights plain language guide for more information.
paragraph2: In cases of human rights [violations], you should review your workplace's rules. If you are in a [union], you should also refer to your [collective agreement] or [union]. A guide to filing a [complaint] with the Alberta Human Rights Commission can be found below.

additionalInformation:
As workers, we must follow health and safety rules. We must not harass others, bully others, or be violent. We must report work conditions that are not safe. This is part of Alberta law.  

It is not always easy, but if we do not follow these rules there can be serious [consequences] (such as injuries).
alertText:
Workplaces in Alberta have been affected by COVID-19. This has left many workers wondering how they can protect themselves from the virus.

Workers continue to have the Right to refuse dangerous work and be free from reprisal, but it is important to follow the correct process under OHS act.

additionalInformation:
It does not matter if the accident was your fault, or if your boss says it was your fault. WCB is “no-fault” insurance for most workplaces.  

If you need help with a WCB report, ask your employer or a co-worker for help. If you are in a union, your union representative may also be able to help. You can also contact WCB. The WCB website includes a video on how to report an injury online as a worker. It is your right to report an injury. You must report an injury to get benefits. You should also report an injury as quickly as possible. 

Confused? Don’t be afraid to call WCB. If they don’t know the answer, they can point you in the right direction.
